abstract: A report from the Working Mother Research Institute finds that whether working or stay-at-home, mothers feel guilty about something.
snippet: A report from the Working Mother Research Institute finds that whether working or stay-at-home, mothers feel guilty about something.
lead_paragraph: In case you missed it, the Working Mother Research Institute surveyed 3,781 women and issued a report called "What Moms Choose." It quantifies a lot of things we know, and a few that we don't. Here are a few statistics to throw out over dinner, if you belong to one of those families who have civilized, discussion-based dinners (I tell myself that will happen when the children are older):

headline.main: Neglected Children, Messy Houses and Guilt
